titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

did.repository: University of Delaware Special Collections Department Morris Library, 181 South College Avenue Newark, DE 19717-5267

bioghist.p: The United States Customs Service (1789-1927) processed paperwork for the import and export of goods into and out of the country. Customs officials also assessed and collected customs fees and penalties. Past functions of the Customs Service included administration of navigation aids and lighthouses, and functions relating to the protection of seamen, and to revenue cutters. In 1927 the Customs Service became the Bureau of Customs.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of the United States Customs Service of the Port of Philadelphia, illustrating commercial and shipping interests, as well as foreign trade relations, of Colonial America and of the United States. The records include: official Customs House records, liquidation entries, affidavits, foreign invoices, general correspondence, consular authentications, and abstracts of duties. There are also four microfilm reels of documents within the collection, 1790-1869, categorized by topic, such as metalwork, clothing, textiles, ceramics, other craftsmen, artists, and occupations. In addition, there is a set of printouts of the U.S. Customs Service archives.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

acqinfo.p: Provenance: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Moyerman.
